Common.Name: Trumpeter Swan
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities. Confidence is low, given low confidence for habitat affinities themselves.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Squires and Anderson 1995 American Midland Naturalist; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Maltese Swan
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities. Confidence is low, given low confidence for habitat affinities themselves.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Alcover 2000 Tropics

Common.Name: Mute Swan
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities. Confidence is low, given low confidence for habitat affinities themselves.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Bailey et al. 2008 The Journal of Wildlife Management; All About Birds 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Birds of the World 2020 Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Common.Name: Flightless Mihirung
Water.Dependence.Notes: Miharungs apparently had salt glands (although evidence of how this is determined is unclear). This suggests an adaptation to drinking saline waters in arid environments.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Murray and Vickers-Rich 2004 Magnificent mihirungs: the colossal flightless birds of the Australian dreamtime

Common.Name: Giant Panda
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Short-faced bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Short-faced bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Florida spectacled bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Spectacled Bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: American Black Bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: American black bears will dig for underground plant parts and cicada nymphs (Lundgren et al. In Preparation). Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Lundgren et al. In Preparation; Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Brown Bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Grizzlies and likely most brown bears dig for underground plant parts, with profound influences on soil mineralization rates, and plant communities (Tardiff and Stanford 1998). Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Tardiff and Stanford 1998 Ecology; Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Cave bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Asiatic Black Bear
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Bears are highly adapted for scratch digging to eat underground plant parts and invertebrates. Indeed, they are considered in some ways ecologically parallel to rooting pigs.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hatley and Kappelman 1980 Human Ecology

Common.Name: Pronghorn
Water.Dependence.Notes: There has been substantial debate about whether pronghorn (particularly those in the hot deserts of North America) require surface water. Evidence suggests that they do. However, like other species, this is likely contingent upon demographics, with lactating females requiring surface water more than non-lactating adults. Overall, water availability has been shown to increase population growth rates and persistence, but some populations exist in hyper-arid deserts without (known) surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Harveson 2006 Pronghorn Symposium; Tluczek 2012 Thesis; Morgart et al. 2005 Wildlife Society Bulletin

Common.Name: Addax
Water.Dependence.Notes: Grazers of harsh deserts, subsisting on desert grasses. Will consume forbs and shrubs during drought, and relishes on bitter melon for water content. Can survive years without drinking water, if forage is of sufficient quality.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hummel et al. 2008 Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Impala
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Hartebeest
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Springbok
Water.Dependence.Notes: Described as avoiding areas with water, potentially to avoid ticks carried in tall grass. Short grass specialists.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Harlan's muskox; helmeted muskox; bonnet-headed muskox
Gaur
Water.Dependence.Notes: Gaur are described as free water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Sankar et al. 2013 Tropical Conservation Science

Common.Name: Banteng
Water.Dependence.Notes: Banteng are described as requiring free water daily.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Steinmetz 2004 Mammalia

Common.Name: Cow
Species.Status: Extinct after 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range

Common.Name: Nilgai
Water.Dependence.Notes: Nilgai distributions are described as being coupled with water availability. I could not find empirical evidence that would distinguish between Low and High water dependence. Given their semi-arid to arid habitats, I imagine they are more free water independent than other more mesic species, but scoring as High to be conservative.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Leslie 2008 Mammalian Species

Common.Name: Wild water buffalo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Water buffalo are closely associated with aquatic habitats. It is highly unlikely that they are free water independent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018; Choudhury 1994 Oryx

Common.Name: Domestic water buffalo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Water buffalo are closely associated with aquatic habitats. It is highly unlikely that they are free water independent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018

Common.Name: Lowland Anoa
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Long-horned Javan water buffalo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Bay Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: Described by Hempson et al. 2015, from Kingdon and Wilson and Mittermeier, as being free water independent, which is surprising given their habitat in lowland rainforest.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Harvey's Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: Denizens of drier forests than other duikers, but often in proximity to water. Thus inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Natal Red Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: Described by Hempson et al. 2015, from Kingdon and Wilson and Mittermeier, as being free water independent, which is surprising given their habitat in lowland rainforest.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Black-fronted Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: Black-fronted duikers inhabit swampy, water-logged habitats along streams. Almost certainly free water dependent, given this habitat affinity.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Red-flanked Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species prefers dense vegetation close to perennial sources of water. Inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Yellow-backed Duiker
Water.Dependence.Notes: Described by Hempson et al. 2015, from Kingdon and Wilson and Mittermeier, as being free water independent, which is surprising given their habitat in lowland rainforest.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Black Wildebeest
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Common Wildebeest
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Topi
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Blesbok
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species is usually in the vicinity of water and is described as free water dependent by Hempson et al. 2015.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Thomson's Gazelle
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Dorcas Gazelle
Water.Dependence.Notes: Dorcas gazelles do not require surface water, however, analysis of their habitat use in the Negev Desert of Israel shows a positive association with access to perennial surface water. This suggests they prefer water, but will go without if necessary.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Henley et al. 2007 Journal of Arid Environments

Common.Name: Mountain Gazelle
Water.Dependence.Notes: May dig for succulent underground plant parts when water is unavailable.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Arabian Sand Gazelle
Water.Dependence.Notes: Arabian sand gazelles are desert generalists, eating a variety of chenopods, grasses, and getting water from bitter wild melons. Can survive for long periods without drinking water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Schulz et al. 2013 Mammalian Biology

Common.Name: Sable Antelope
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Waterbuck
Water.Dependence.Notes: A denizen of wetland habitats. Described as free water dependent by Hempson et al., and his sources.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Kob
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Southern Lechwe
Water.Dependence.Notes: A denizen of aquatic and semi-aquatic habitats. Inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Nile Lechwe
Water.Dependence.Notes: A denizen of aquatic and semi-aquatic habitats. Inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Puku
Water.Dependence.Notes: A denizen of aquatic and semi-aquatic habitats. Inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Gerenuk
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Chinese Goral
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species habitat is closely linked to surface water. Inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Grant's Gazelle
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Klipspringer
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Beisa Oryx
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Scimitar-horned Oryx
Species.Status: Extinct after 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range

Common.Name: Gemsbok
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species is largely free water independent, but will dig wells to groundwater.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hamilton et al. 1977 Madoqua
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Gemsbok, in conjunction with Papio ursinus, dig wells to ground water in West Africa. These wells reach a meter or more in depth.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hamilton et al. 1977 Madoqua

Common.Name: Arabian Oryx
Water.Dependence.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) water usage
Water.Dependence.Notes: A free water independent species of arid to semi-arid deserts. Little is known about them in the wild because of their population decline.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Ismail et al. 2011 Journal of Arid Environments

Common.Name: Oribi
Water.Dependence.Notes: Thought to be free-water independent yet proximity to water does appear to be important in more arid parts of their range.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bighorn Sheep
Water.Dependence.Notes: Bighorn sheep population persistence is strongly associated with water availability, although this is often contested. Some authors posit that certain populations (likely with sufficient forage) can be free water independent. Their water requirements are probably structured by demographics, with lactating ewes requiring more water than non-lactating ewes or rams.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Longshore et al. 2009 Journal of Arid Environments; Krausman 1996 Desert bighorn sheep and water: a bibliography

Common.Name: Maxwell's Duiker
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Steenbok
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Southern Reedbuck
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Mountain Reedbuck
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bohor Reedbuck
Water.Dependence.Notes: A water dependent species according to Wilson and Mittermeier and Pacini and Harper.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Common Duiker
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: African Buffalo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Free water availability limits their otherwise broad distribution.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Nyala
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Lesser Kudu
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species is considered free water independent, but much remains unknown.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Common Eland
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bushbuck
Water.Dependence.Notes: Their distribution is closely linked to surface water availability.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Sitatunga
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species' semi-aquatic adaptations, it is almost certainly surface water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Greater Kudu
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Dromedary camel
Species.Status: Extinct before 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range
Water.Dependence.Notes: Camels can go up to 7 months without drinking water. Highly arid adapted. The difference in water retention ability between bactrian and dromedary camels is unclear.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Bactrian Camel
Water.Dependence.Notes: Camels can go up to 7 months without drinking water. Highly arid adapted. The difference in water retention ability between bactrian and dromedary camels is unclear.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Moose
Water.Dependence.Notes: Moose distributions are closely linked to aquatic habitats. Unclear if they are actually require free water, but is highly likely.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Marsh Deer
Water.Dependence.Notes: Unclear if this species requires free water, but it is likely given their functional adaptations for wetland habitats, for which they appear to be obligate users.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Common Fallow Deer; European Fallow Deer; Fallow Deer
Tufted Deer
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species' habitat is often associated with water. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Pere David's Deer
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities. Confidence is low, given low confidence for habitat affinities themselves.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Taruca
Water.Dependence.Notes: Closely associated with water points. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Peruvian Dwarf Brocket; Common Dwarf Brocket
Central American Red Brocket; Mexican Red Brocket

Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species' almost certain aquatic habitat affinities, we are going to infer free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Croitor 2016 Geobios

Common.Name: Mule Deer
Water.Dependence.Notes: Female mule deer water nightly during the summer in Arizona, consuming 5.1 liters per visit. Males do not predictably drink water. During cooler months, females visit water less frequently.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hervert and Krausman 1986 The Journal of Wildlife Management

Common.Name: Barasingha
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species' semi-aquatic habits, it almost certainly free water depdent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Giraffe
Water.Dependence.Notes: Giraffes can survive without drinking surface water, but will drink if available.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Pygmy Hippopotamus
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities. Confidence is low, given low confidence for habitat affinities themselves.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Asian Hippopotamus
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species likely had a similar habit as H. amphibius and was thus likely free water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; Takai et al. 2011 Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology

Common.Name: Common Hippopotamus
Water.Dependence.Notes: Obligate water user.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Madagascan Dwarf Hippopotamus; Malagasy Hippo
Water.Dependence.Notes: These extinct hippos were almost certainly free water dependent, given their aquatic habitat affinities.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Stuenes 1989 Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology

Water.Dependence.Notes: No empirical evidence, but given the likely aquatic habits of this species, they were most likely free water dependent.

Digging.Rooting.Notes: This species was recorded as rooting like pigs, but there seems to have been a scholarship error in recording the proper source. Consider this designation suspect.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: DeSantis et al. 2017

Common.Name: Agile Wallaby
Water.Dependence.Notes: Exact water requirements are unclear. They do dig shallow wells to groundwater, suggesting that they aren't completely free water independent.
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Agile wallabies dig shallow wells to ground water (~20 cm), apparently to avoid crocodile predation on river banks.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Doody et al. 2007 Ethology

Common.Name: Antilopine Wallaroo
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species requires free water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Western Gray Kangaroo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Habitat is generally in close proximity to surface water. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Whiptail Wallaby
Water.Dependence.Method: Observed low sample size (1-5) water usage
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species is mostly free-water independent, except during severe drought.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Common Wallaroo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Although largely free-water independent, wallaroos are described as digging wells to groundwater in creek beds.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Wallaroos dig wells to ground water, but nothing is known except for one photo in the Handbook of the Mammals of the World. The well looks ~20 cm in depth.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Red Kangaroo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Red kangaroos can go days without drinking water, but ultimately do require it.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Giant Short-faced Kangaroo
Water.Dependence.Notes: Prideaux et al. 2009 presented compelling evidence that this kangaroo was a chenopod specialist. Chenopods have high sodium concentrations, requiring either specialized adaptations for reabsorbing water or increased reliance on free water. Oxygen isotopes (which vary between leaf-water and free water)  indicate that this species indeed was significantly more free water dependent than extant, arid-adapted kangaroos. Prideaux suggests that their hoofed morphology made them highly mobile to track ephemeral and intermittent water sources across their arid habitat.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Prideaux et al. 2009 PNAS

Common.Name: Northern Hairy-nosed Wombat
Water.Dependence.Notes: These wombats have the driest dung of almost any mammal. Almost entirely free water independent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Southern Hairy-nosed Wombat
Water.Dependence.Notes: These wombats have the driest dung of almost any mammal. Almost entirely free water independent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Giant Wombat
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Dawson 2006 claims that these giant wombats dug burrows or trenches. However, Woolnough and Steel 2001 analyzed the morphometrics of wombats and concluded that burrowing would have been very unlikely at this body size. Instead, they suggest they were probably scratch-diggers exclusively.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Dawson 2006 Alcheringa; Woolnough and Steele 2001 Mammal Review

Common.Name: Hackett's Wombat
Water.Dependence.Method: Inferred from habitat affinities; Inferred from extant relatives
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species survived an extreme aridification event in the SW Australia. Likewise, its relatives (the hairy nosed wombats) are extremely free water independent. We think it is safe to infer free water independence for this extinct taxa.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Johnson and Prideaux 2004 Austral Ecology; Prideaux et al. 2010 PNAS; Jankowski et al. 2016 Journal of Quaternary Science
Digging.Rooting.Notes: This species was small enough to probably burrow like its extant relatives.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Woolnough and Steele 2001 Mammal Review

Common.Name: Common Wombat
Water.Dependence.Notes: Unclear exactly how to rank this species. They are described as less surface water dependent than the hairy nosed wombats, which are arid-zone denizens. Ranking as 'Low'.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2015 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Wombats are consummate diggers, and have also been recorded digging a ~4m deep well to groundwater (on one occasion).
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Millington 2020 ABC

Common.Name: Warendja
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Lacks the morphology for effective burrowing (Woolnough and Steele 2001)
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Woolnough and Steele 2001 Mammal Review

Common.Name: Xenorhinotherium
Water.Dependence.Notes: Isotopic data indicate a habitat of hot, dry, open environments. This suggests the possibility of free water independence. Not confident enough to assign a trait value.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Lobo 2015 Thesis; de Oliveira et al. 2020 Quaternary Science Reviews

Water.Dependence.Notes: No empirical evidence, but given the likely aquatic habits of this species, they were most likely free water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: NA

Common.Name: African Wild Ass
Water.Dependence.Notes: African asses and donkeys are highly free water independent, but  require daily drinking water during high temperatures, especially if lactating. Donkeys can survive up to a 30% loss in bodyweight from water loss, and can survive 12 days without water. Incredibly, they are able to drink enough water in (24-30L) in 2-5 minutes to restore this deficit.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hampson et al. 2010 Equine Veternary Journal
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Introduced donkeys dig up to 1.5m to reach groundwater.

Common.Name: Donkey
Water.Dependence.Notes: Donkeys, like African asses, are highly free water independent, but  require daily drinking water during high temperatures, especially if lactating. Donkeys can survive up to a 30% loss in bodyweight from water loss, and can survive 12 days without water. Incredibly, they are able to drink enough water in (24-30L) in 2-5 minutes to restore this deficit.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Hampson et al. 2010 Equine Veternary Journal
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Introduced donkeys dig up to 1.5m to reach groundwater.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Lundgren et al. 2018 Ecography

Common.Name: Wild horse
Water.Dependence.Notes: Horses are less arid adapted than asses, usually requiring daily water intake. However, desert dwelling horses appear capable of adapting to aridity: central Australian feral horses travelled from foraging grounds to water points as infrequently as every 4 days.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hampson et al. 2010 Equine Veternary Journal
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Introduced horses dig up to 1.5 m to groundwater.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Lundgren et al. 2020 In Review

Common.Name: Horse
Water.Dependence.Notes: Horses are less arid adapted than asses, usually requiring daily water intake. However, desert dwelling horses appear capable of adapting to aridity: central Australian feral horses travelled from foraging grounds to water points as infrequently as every 4 days.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hampson et al. 2010 Equine Veternary Journal
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Introduced horses dig up to 1.5 m to groundwater.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Lundgren et al. 2020 In Review

Common.Name: Grevy's Zebra
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Grevy's zebras have been described digging in drying streams in East Africa. Their wells become used by livestock and other wildlife.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: J.L. Lekenit personal comm

Common.Name: Asiatic Wild Ass
Water.Dependence.Notes: Payne et al. 2020 found that Asiatic wild ass visit water sources every 1.5-2.2 days during the hot season, and every 2.2-3.8 days during the cool season. In areas with human presence they visited waters at night, but in remote areas without humans, they visited any time of day. During the winter, if there was sufficient snow, they could go long periods of time without drinking water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Payne et al. 2020 Scientific Reports
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Asiatic asses dig wells to groundwater, generally around 50cm in depth, but probably also to 1.5m in depth like donkeys.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: P. Kaczensky personal communication; Payne et al. 2020 Scientific reports

Common.Name: Plains Zebra
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Mountain Zebra
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Sumatran Rhinoceros
Water.Dependence.Notes: Inferring free water dependence from habitat affinities
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Black Rhinoceros
Water.Dependence.Notes: This species is free water dependent, but can go up to 5 days without drinking water‚Äìif dispersing.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Javan Rhinoceros
Water.Dependence.Notes: Heavily utilize aquatic habitats. Water dependence appears to be a common trait for all rhinos.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Greater One-horned Rhino
Water.Dependence.Notes: Free water dependent, rarely venturing >2km from perennial water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World

Common.Name: Giant Tapir
Water.Dependence.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from habitat association
Water.Dependence.Notes: No empirical evidence, but given the aquatic tendencies of this genus, going to score as free water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: NA

Common.Name: Baird's Tapir
Water.Dependence.Notes: Closely associated with water and wetlands. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018; Gingerich 2003 Paleobiology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Malay Tapir
Water.Dependence.Notes: Closely associated with water and wetlands. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology; IUCN Redlist 2018; Gingerich 2003 Paleobiology; Pacini and Harper 2008 Tropical stream ecology

Common.Name: Merriam's Tapir
Water.Dependence.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from habitat association
Water.Dependence.Notes: Closely associated with water and wetlands. Inferring free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: San Diego Zoo Fact Sheets

Water.Dependence.Method: Inferred from Genus; Inferred from habitat association
Water.Dependence.Notes: No empirical evidence, but given the aquatic tendencies of this genus, going to score as free water dependent.
Water.Dependence.Reference: NA

Common.Name: Vero Tapir; California Tapir

Water.Dependence.Reference: NA

Digging.Rooting.Reference: Pujos et al. 2012 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Olive Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Yellow Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Hamadryas Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Kinda Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Guinea Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa

Common.Name: Chacma Baboon
Water.Dependence.Notes: All Papio species require surface water.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2013 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Chacma baboons elaborate wells dug initially by gemsbok in West African deserts. They have a hard time digging in dry sand, but as soon as wells reach water table and sand becomes moist, there are adept as scooping sand out with their hands.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Hamilton et al. 1977 Madoqua

Common.Name: Asian Elephant
Water.Dependence.Notes: African and Asian elephants are water dependent, with water availability structuring their movements and habitat usage.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Dunkin et al. 2013 The Journal of Experimental Biology
Digging.Rooting.Notes: Asian elephants will dig for roots and also to reach ground water. The depths they are willing to dig are unclear.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; L. Baker personal communication; A.A. Sha personal communication

Common.Name: African Elephant
Water.Dependence.Notes: African and Asian elephants are water dependent, with water availability structuring their movements and habitat usage.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Hempson et al. 2015 Science; Kingdon et al. 2013 Mammals of Africa; Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Dunkin et al. 2013 The Journal of Experimental Biology
Digging.Rooting.Notes: African elephants dig for roots and to access groundwater, digging perhaps as deep as 2-3 m.
Digging.Rooting.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2011 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Payne 1999 Silent Thunder; Haynes 2012 Geomorphology

Common.Name: American Beaver
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Milligan and Humphries 2010 Oikos; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Eurasian Beaver
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Beaver
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species aquatic habitat affinities, we are inferring water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Rybczynski 2007 Journal of Mammalian Evolution

Common.Name: Capybara
Water.Dependence.Notes: Capybaras are almost certainly free water dependent given their semi-aquatic habits.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Lesser Capybara
Water.Dependence.Notes: Capybaras are almost certainly free water dependent given their semi-aquatic habits.
Water.Dependence.Reference: Wilson and Mittermeier 2016 Handbook of the Mammals of the World; Wilman et al. 2014 Ecology

Common.Name: Giant Capybara
Water.Dependence.Notes: Given this species' almost certain aquatic habitat affinities, we are going to infer free water dependence.
Water.Dependence.Reference: MacFadden and Shockey 1997 Paleobiology; Perez et al. 2017 Journal of Mammalian Evolution
